content:
The normal way to write a function that constructs a structure is to start the definition body with a { and end it with a corresponding }.
If there is some field (say the first one) which is sufficiently complicated and needs to be referred to several times in other fields, then we sometimes make it a separate definition--I think this doesn't come up that often though.

Reid Barton said:

The other thing about using let in a definition is that you will need to deal with the let again when proving things about the definition

I honestly didn't think about that (I thought that let ... in gets converted to an IIFE internally). There are still plenty of things I have to learn to be good at Lean.
Patrick Johnson has marked this topic as resolved.

To some extent this is a stylistic convention, i.e., we don't have a lot of tools for dealing with let in definitions because we don't use let in definitions and we don't use let in definitions because we don't have a lot of tools for dealing with let in definitions
